feed.title: Combined summary - Benchmarking Bitcoin Script Evaluation for the Varops Budget (Great Script Restoration)

entry.title: Combined summary - Benchmarking Bitcoin Script Evaluation for the Varops Budget (Great Script Restoration)
entry.summary: The introduction of a new Tapscript leaf version aims to address issues that led to the disabling of many opcodes in Bitcoin script execution version 0.3.1 by mitigating denial-of-service attacks through the exploitation of excessive computational time and memory usage. The proposed solution involves generalizing the sigops budget into a varops budget, which is linked to transaction weight, allowing for more compute units proportional to larger transactions. This approach's feasibility and efficiency are determined through benchmarking, focusing on block-sized scripts and various operational patterns to identify the slowest possible script validation scenarios under the new system. The community's involvement is crucial in refining the varops budget, with developers encouraged to participate by checking out the GSR prototype implementation, compiling it with benchmarks enabled, and running specific benchmarks. These activities are pivotal for adjusting and validating the proposed budget, ensuring its reliability and functionality across different systems. Detailed information and opportunities for contribution can be found in the provided GitHub links to both the BIP documentation and the GSR prototype implementation branch. Benchmark compilation settings require careful configuration to ensure comparable results, with suggestions to use specific build options and conditional compilation techniques. Establishing a Git repository for submitting benchmark data via Pull Requests has been proposed to improve data organization and accessibility. The discussion acknowledges errors encountered during benchmarks, emphasizing the need to refine benchmarking approaches for specific operations. The effectiveness of capping the varops budget at 100% is debated, suggesting that removing this cap could provide more insightful data regarding operational counts and performance across different input sizes. The conversation also highlights the complexity of deriving meaningful data from benchmarks due to numerous variables involved. Surprising findings about the performance of hashing algorithms on certain hardware suggest further investigation into operation costs and stack setup might yield more accurate benchmarks. This reflects a deeper understanding of script execution efficiency's real-world implications and the potential need for reevaluating hardcoded operational cost factors in programming environments. Concerns are raised about using the worst-case scenario as the benchmark for average performance, particularly in the context of Bitcoin verification times. It suggests that aiming for faster validation times, possibly on the order of 100ms, might be more appropriate considering the high computational budget limit, which likely means average block validation will be significantly quicker than worst-case scenarios. The conversation touches upon the importance of benchmarks on real blocks and exploring the capabilities of new opcodes, such as those enabling zero-knowledge proofs, to understand better the potential for verifying complex scripts within practical compute time constraints.
